newsitem.title: USA: Startup taps executives' wallets to raise funding.
newsitem.headline: Startup taps executives' wallets to raise funding.

text.p: Silicon Valley startup CrossRoads Software aims to become a neutral zone for the industry, linking business software applications from rival firms.

To accomplish this, and also to raise financing, the company has struck on a novel approach -- tapping the wallets of executives who are each other's fierce rivals but whose complex products CrossRoads seeks to integrate.

Founded a year ago, the California-based CrossRoads aims to connect software from different vendors by creating reusable "bridges" that can be used to join together enormous and otherwise incompatible systems.

CrossRoads chief executive Katrina Garnett said the company recently raised $12.6 million from a financing round which included three corporations and 50 influential individuals, half of whom are top high-tech executives.

The carefully choreographed team of investors includes manufacturing and financial software giant SAP AG -- a leader in the industry around whose products many companies have rebuilt their entire businesses -- and the services and consulting firm Ernst & Young LLP.

But the investor pool also includes a Who's Who of the software business applications universe, including PeopleSoft CEO Dave Duffield, Vantive Corp CEO John Luongo, Scopus Technology CEO Ori Sasson and Clarify CEO Dave Stamm.

Already the company has lined up strategic alliances with those companies and with Baan, paving the way for it to offer "out of the box" software to achieve the sort of integration the big players cannot.

CrossRoads, which is due to be formally launched next month, plans to link products of these companies through a combination of application-independent modules and connectors, which work with specific programmes.
Garnett, a veteran of Oracle Corp. and Sybase, said that by drawing investors from among its partners, CrossRoads has created an additional barrier to entry against other potential competitors.

"Basically, I targeted the companies that are my partners, to build a real defence (against new entrants) -- the presidents and CEOs, the COOs, the vice chairman and VPs of sales of all my partner companies," she said.
The investor pool of industry heavy hitters brings some ardent adversaries together behind one company.
Some venture investors agree the structure may make it more difficult for others to enter the business, although it could result in a potential for conflicts of interest.
Others, including Terence Garnett, husband of CrossRoads' CEO and a venture partner at Venrock Associates, said this could be a new model for startups.
The Garnetts provided initial capital for the venture, and Venrock, the Rockefeller family's venture capital group, participated in the recent round of finance.

The annual world market for packaged business software -- used in tasks from tracking employee records to manufacturing and procurement -- is estimated at $27 billion, or $44 billion including computer hardware.
Crossroads said it expects to ship its initial products in the middle of the fourth quarter this year.
